Formative Assessments

NoteShare your Workbook



You must not be shy or embarrassed to share your workbook. Nobody will judge you. We are all learning!

title: Assessment Brief 2025-26
text:
Type of Assessment
Your Summative is to produce an dynamic document (i.e.¬†a simple Quarto document) containing an analytical workflow for a given dataset where critically interpret the results and draw your conclusions.

Step 1 - Context
You will be given a context of a scientific problem. This context will introduce you to a real-world problem that is going to be used as a background for the data that you are going to analyse.


Step 2 - The dataset
You will have access to a pre-built dataset in a .csv format that will contain all the data and metadata needed for your analyses. The data is the same for everyone and I am not providing data on your specific subject of studies.


Step 3 - Your Workbook
You are going to work on the assessment using your Quarto workbook constructed over the course of the whole module. This is going to be your submission. I‚Äôll collect your exams using a NOW Dropbox where you can paste the link to your published workbook.






Note



The dataset and context description for the Summative exam will be shared by the end of the module sessions (probably in the last week of classes).

title: Summative Brief
text: Impact of Habitat Fragmentation on Amphibian Biodiversity

title: Summative Brief
text:
1 - Data Exploration:
Your initial task is to perform a thorough data exploration to understand its characteristics, identify potential issues, and generate initial hypotheses before proceeding with formal statistical modeling.
Specific aspects to address during data exploration:

Data Types: Identify the type of each variable (numerical, categorical, discrete, continuous).
Missing Values: Check for and quantify any missing data points. How might you address them?
Distributions: Examine the distributions of key numerical variables (e.g., Patch Size, Isolation Index, Amphibian Species Count, Total Amphibian Abundance) using appropriate graphical methods (histograms, box plots, density plots). Comment on skewness, outliers, and multimodality.
Summary Statistics: Calculate relevant descriptive statistics (mean, median, standard deviation, quartiles, min/max) for numerical variables. Provide frequency tables and proportions for categorical variables.

title: Summative Brief
text:
2 - Explore relationships between variables:

Explore relationships between numerical variables using scatter plots (e.g., Patch Size vs.¬†Amphibian Species Count, Isolation Index vs.¬†Total Amphibian Abundance). Look for trends, correlations, and potential non-linear relationships.
Use box plots or violin plots to visualize the distribution of numerical variables across different categories (e.g., Amphibian Species Count by Dominant Vegetation Type, Total Amphibian Abundance by Presence/Absence of Key Predator).
Consider how to visualize changes over time (e.g., trends in species count or abundance across survey years).
Data Consistency/Plausibility Checks: Are there any values that seem unrealistic or incorrect (e.g., negative patch sizes, unusually high or low counts)?
Formulate Initial Hypotheses: Based on your exploratory analysis, propose initial hypotheses about the relationships between habitat fragmentation and amphibian populations.

title: Summative Brief
text:
3 - Test your hypothesis

Now, based on the previous steps, set a scientific hypotheses and test it with one an appropriate statistic model. Remember that sometimes, hypotheses can be tested using different pieces of evidence. This means that you can use different tests and models to collect evidence of your scientific hypothesis.

title: Summative Brief
text:
4 - Summarise your results
Now, just write commenting on your results and how these corroborate, or not, your hypothesis. Connect your discourse with results (tables and figures).

title: Summative Brief
section: 5 - Publish your work as a dynamic report using Quarto (either as a PDF or as a website).
text:
5 - Publish your work as a dynamic report using Quarto (either as a PDF or as a website).
At this point and after working across all Module using a Quarto Workbook, you must be able to publish your work as a dynamic report that makes me able to follow your woirkflor and check whther the learnign objective were achieved.

title: Summative Brief
text:
6 - Submit it to NOW Dropbox
At NTU there is only one way to submit your work which is via DropBox. You can then just upload your PDF or use the comment box to paste the link to your work.

title: Programa do Curso
text:

Bora, mospirraia! üëã
Se voc√™ est√° aqui, provavelmente j√° percebeu que a Ecologia de Paisagens n√£o √© apenas ‚Äúmais uma disciplina de ecologia‚Äù. √â, na verdade, o seu novo ‚Äúsuperpoder‚Äù profissional. Aqui v√£o tr√™s motivos (sem enrola√ß√£o) pra voc√™ se empolgar com o que vem por a√≠:

1. O fim do ‚ÄúEc√≥logo de Laborat√≥rio‚Äù üî¨‚û°Ô∏èüó∫Ô∏è
O mercado de trabalho atual (seja em consultoria ambiental, ONGs ou gest√£o p√∫blica) n√£o quer mais algu√©m que s√≥ saiba identificar uma esp√©cie dentro de um potinho. Eles precisam de quem consiga olhar para uma imagem de sat√©lite e dizer: ‚ÄúSe a gente desmatar aquele pedacinho ali, a gente isola a popula√ß√£o inteira do outro lado do rio‚Äù. A Ecologia de Paisagens te tira da escala da formiga e te coloca na escala do planejamento territorial. √â onde as grandes decis√µes acontecem.


2. Voc√™ vai falar a l√≠ngua dos tomadores de decis√£o üó£Ô∏èüíº

Isso traz autoridade. 3. A ‚ÄúEcologia Pol√≠tica‚Äù √© a vida real üåçü§ù

O ‚ÄúPulo do Gato‚Äù:

Essas s√£o as ferramentas que v√£o te dar autonomia. Ent√£o, quando o c√≥digo der erro ou o conceito de escala parecer abstrato demais, lembre-se: voc√™ est√° construindo o seu canivete su√≠√ßo profissional. O mundo l√° fora est√° fragmentado e precisando de gente capaz de reconectar os peda√ßos.

title: Programa do Curso
text:
Materiais do curso
Todas as leituras e softwares nesta classe s√£o gratuitos. Existem vers√µes online gratuitas de todos os livros did√°ticos; R e RStudio s√£o inerentemente gratuitos. Usaremos diferentes fontes de v√≠deos, e-books, f√≥runs e conjuntos de dados, todos dispon√≠veis gratuitamente e amplamente utilizados no ambiente online de aprendizagem de R e estat√≠stica.
Confiaremos fortemente nestes livros, que est√£o todos dispon√≠veis online (de gra√ßa!).
Ocasionalmente, haver√° artigos e v√≠deos adicionais para ler e assistir. Quando isso acontecer, os links para esses outros recursos ser√£o inclu√≠dos na p√°gina de conte√∫do daquela sess√£o.

R e RStudio
Voc√™ far√° toda a sua an√°lise com a linguagem de programa√ß√£o de c√≥digo aberto (e gratuita!) R. Voc√™ usar√° o RStudio como o programa principal para acessar o R. Pense no R como um motor e no RStudio como o painel de um carro ‚Äî o R lida com todos os c√°lculos, produz as estat√≠sticas reais e a sa√≠da gr√°fica, enquanto o RStudio fornece uma interface agrad√°vel para executar o c√≥digo R.
O R √© gratuito, mas √†s vezes pode ser um inc√¥modo para instalar e configurar. Para facilitar a vida, voc√™ pode (e deve!) usar o servi√ßo gratuito Posit.cloud, que permite executar uma inst√¢ncia completa do RStudio no seu navegador web. Isso significa que voc√™ n√£o ter√° que instalar nada no seu computador para come√ßar com o R! Teremos um espa√ßo de trabalho compartilhado da classe no Posit.cloud que permitir√° copiar rapidamente modelos de exemplos, exerc√≠cios e mini projetos.
O Posit.cloud √© conveniente, mas pode ser lento e n√£o foi projetado para lidar com conjuntos de dados maiores ou an√°lises e gr√°ficos mais complicados. Voc√™ tamb√©m n√£o pode usar suas pr√≥prias fontes personalizadas com o Posit.cloud. Ao longo do semestre, voc√™ provavelmente desejar√° instalar o R, o RStudio e outros pacotes de R no seu computador e se desmamar do Posit.cloud. Isso n√£o √© 100% necess√°rio, mas √© √∫til.
Voc√™ pode encontrar instru√ß√µes para instalar o R, RStudio e todos os pacotes do tidyverse aqui.


Buscando e encontrando ajuda
A gente sabe que aprender a lidar com dados e conceitos espaciais d√° um n√≥ na cabe√ßa √†s vezes. Quando o erro aparece no R ou o conceito de ‚Äúextens√£o‚Äù parece fugir da mente, a vontade √© correr pro ChatGPT e pedir a resposta, n√©? Mas √≥, se voc√™ fizer isso, voc√™ n√£o est√° treinando seu c√©rebro, est√° apenas treinando a IA.
Para este curso, vamos adotar a ‚ÄúPol√≠tica dos 3 Passos‚Äù para o suporte. O objetivo √© transformar voc√™ em um profissional independente que sabe se virar no mundo real.
üõ†Ô∏è O Workflow da Autonomia (Antes de pedir socorro) Se voc√™ travou, siga esta ordem. √â o caminho que qualquer ec√≥logo ou cientista de dados s√™nior faz:
Google & StackOverflow (O Or√°culo): 99% dos erros de c√≥digo j√° aconteceram com algu√©m. Copie o erro do R e cole no Google. Se for um conceito te√≥rico, a Wikipedia (especialmente em ingl√™s) e os nossos livros online s√£o seus melhores amigos.
Documenta√ß√£o Oficial: No R, digite ?nome_do_pacote. Ler o manual parece chato, mas √© onde mora a verdade.
A Comunidade (N√≥s!): N√£o resolveu? Traga para a pr√≥xima aula. Explique o que voc√™ j√° tentou. Seus colegas ou eu vamos te dar um empurr√£ozinho (e n√£o a resposta pronta).

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text: This tutorial provides an introduction to creating a basic webpage using Quarto within RStudio. Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, allows you to author dynamic content and can render to various formats, including websites.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text: This tutorial provides an introduction to creating a basic webpage using Quarto within RStudio. Quarto, the next-generation version of R Markdown, allows you to author dynamic content and can render to various formats, including websites.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Your workbook
While learning stats and coding, you‚Äôll also learn how to build and publish simple websites using R and RStudio. This website is vital for you learning during this module. This is going to be your live coursebook.
See some examples how NTU students used this for the summative last year:

Example 1
Example 2







TipInvest on your worbook



Your workbook is going to be your ‚Äúbest friend‚Äù during this module. There you can experiment, create personal notes and gather bibliography. It works like a paper notebook, but it is a website.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Prerequisites
Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

R installed on your computer.
RStudio installed on your computer.
The quarto package may need to be installed if you intend to render from the R console:


install.packages("quarto")

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
section: Creating a Quarto Project (Recommended for Websites)
text:
Creating a Quarto Project (Recommended for Websites)
While not explicitly detailed in these short excerpts, for creating a webpage (which often involves multiple pages and assets), it is generally recommended to start with a Quarto project. This helps organise your website files.

In RStudio, go to File > New Project‚Ä¶.
Choose New Directory.
Select Quarto Project.
Choose a name for your project and a location to save it.
Click Create Project.

This will create a basic Quarto project structure.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Creating Your Webpage Content
Webpages in a Quarto website are typically created as .qmd files, similar to standard Quarto documents.

Within your Quarto project, go to File > New File > Quarto Document‚Ä¶.
Choose your desired default format (this might be less critical for individual content pages within a website structure, as the website configuration will largely dictate the final output). Click Create.
This will open a new .qmd file where you can write your webpage content using a combination of:

YAML Header: Each page can have an optional YAML header (demarcated by --- at the start and end) to specify metadata like the title.
---
title: "My Webpage"
---
Markdown Text: Use standard Markdown syntax to format your text, headings, lists, links, images, etc.. RStudio‚Äôs Visual editor can be helpful for this, offering a WYSIWYM experience [1]. You can switch between Visual and Source modes using the toolbar or the shortcut ‚åò‚áß F4 (macOS) or Ctrl+Shift+F4 (Windows/Linux) [1].
Code Chunks: You can embed and execute code (primarily R in this context, indicated by ```{r}) within your webpage to create dynamic content [2, 3]. You can run individual code chunks interactively in RStudio by clicking the Run icon or using the keyboard shortcut (‚áß‚åò‚èé on macOS or Ctrl+Shift+Enter on Windows/Linux).

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Configuring Your Quarto Website
Creating a multi-page website with Quarto involves a configuration file, typically named _quarto.yml, in the root of your project. This file defines the navigation, theme, and other website-level settings.
Note: The provided sources do not contain specific details on the structure and content of the _quarto.yml file. However, based on Quarto‚Äôs nature as a next-generation version of R Markdown [4], it leverages YAML for configuration. You would typically define your website‚Äôs navigation links to your different .qmd content pages within this file.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Rendering Your Quarto Webpage(s)
Once you have your content pages (.qmd files) and your website configuration (_quarto.yml`), you can render your website.

In RStudio, with your Quarto project open, you can typically use the Build pane. Look for a Render Website option. Clicking this will process your project files according to your _quarto.yml configuration and generate your website.
Alternatively, you might be able to render the entire website from the R console within your project directory using the quarto package, though the specific command for a website render isn‚Äôt detailed in the excerpts. It would likely be related to the quarto::quarto_render() function but applied at the project level.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Previewing Your Webpage
After rendering, Quarto will generate the necessary HTML and other files for your website. You can usually preview your webpage by looking a the Viewer tab in bottom-right panel of your Rstudio window.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Further Steps
This tutorial provides a basic introduction. Creating a full-fledged website with Quarto involves learning more about:

The _quarto.yml configuration file to control navigation, theme, and other website settings.
Organising your content into multiple .qmd pages.
Using themes to style your website.
Including assets like images and CSS files.

This is a starting point to introduce Quarto as a tool capable of creating websites and its reliance on .qmd files and YAML. You would need to consult further Quarto documentation for detailed instructions on website creation.
By following these initial steps, you can begin to explore the possibilities of creating webpages with Quarto in RStudio.

title: Tutorial: Getting Started with a Quarto Webpage
text:
Publish your workbook
There are many ways to publish your workbook and you might chose simple or more advanced ways.

Simple Rpubs page

title: Using Quarto
text:
Quarto Markdown is regular Markdown with R code and output sprinkled in. You can do everything you can with regular Markdown, but you can incorporate graphs, tables, and other code output directly in your document. You can create HTML, PDF, and Word documents, PowerPoint and HTML presentations, websites, books, and even interactive dashboards with Quarto. This whole course website is created with Quarto.
Quarto‚Äôs predecessor was called R Markdown and worked exclusively with R (though there are ways to use other languages in document). Quarto is essentially ‚ÄúR Markdown 2.0,‚Äù but it is designed to be language agnostic. You can use R, Python, Julia, Observable JS, and even Stata code all in the same document. It is magical.
Here are the most important things you‚Äôll need to know about Quarto in this class:

title: Using Quarto
text:
Key terms

Document: A Markdown file where you type stuff
Chunk: A piece of R code that is included in your document. It looks like this:
```{r}
# Code goes here
1 + 1
```
There must be an empty line before and after the chunk. The final three backticks must be the only thing on the line‚Äîif you add more text, or if you forget to add the backticks, or accidentally delete the backticks, your document will not render correctly.
Render: When you render a document, R runs each of the chunks sequentially and converts the output of each chunk into Markdown. R then runs the document through pandoc to convert it to HTML or PDF or Word (or whatever output you‚Äôve selected).
You can render by clicking on the ‚ÄúRender‚Äù button at the top of the editor window, or by pressing ‚åò‚áßK on macOS or control + shift + K on Windows.

::: {.cell layout-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù} ::: {.cell-output-display}  ::: :::

title: Using Quarto
text:
Add chunks
There are three ways to insert chunks:

Press ‚åò‚å•I on macOS or control + alt + I on Windows
Click on the ‚ÄúInsert‚Äù button at the top of the editor window

::: {.cell layout-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù} ::: {.cell-output-display}  ::: :::

Manually type all the backticks and curly braces (don‚Äôt do this)

title: Using Quarto
text:
Chunk names
You can add names to chunks to make it easier to navigate your document. If you click on the little dropdown menu at the bottom of your editor in RStudio, you can see a table of contents that shows all the headings and chunks. If you name chunks, they‚Äôll appear in the list. If you don‚Äôt include a name, the chunk will still show up, but you won‚Äôt know what it does.









There are two ways to add a chunk name:

As a special comment called label:, following #| at the top of the chunk (this is the preferred way):
```{r}
#| label: name-of-this-chunk

1 + 1
```
Immediately after the {r in the first line of the chunk (this is the older way):
```{r name-of-this-chunk}
1 + 1
```

Names cannot contain spaces, but they can contain underscores and dashes. All chunk names in your document must be unique.

title: Using Quarto
text:
Chunk options
There are a bunch of different options you can set for each chunk. You can see a complete list in the R Markdown Reference Guide or at {knitr}‚Äôs website.
Set chunk options as special comments following #| at the top of the chunk (this is the preferred way):
```{r}
#| label: fig-some-plot
#| fig-cap: "Here's a caption for this plot"
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-height: 4
#| echo: false

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = drv)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")
```
Technically you can also set these options inside the {r} section of the chunk‚Äîthis is the old way to do it, but it gets really gross and long when you have lots of settings:
{r fig-some-plot, fig.width=6, fig.height=4, echo=FALSE, fig.cap = "Here's a caption for this plot"}
Here are some of the most common chunk options you‚Äôll use in this class:

label: fig-whatever: Try to always use chunk labels. If you want things to be cross-referenceable, use a fig- prefix on chunks that make figures and a tbl- prefix on chunks that make tables
tbl-cap: "Blah": Add a caption to your table
fig-cap: "Blah": Add a caption to your figure
fig-width: 5 and fig-height: 3 (or whatever number you want): Set the dimensions for figures
echo: false: The code is not shown in the final document, but the results are
message: false: Any messages that R generates (like all the notes that appear after you load a package) are omitted
warning: false: Any warnings that R generates are omitted
include: false: The chunk still runs, but the code and results are not included in the final document

title: Using Quarto
text:
Inline chunks
You can also include R output directly in your text, which is really helpful if you want to report numbers from your analysis. To do this, use `r r_code_here`.
It‚Äôs generally easiest to calculate numbers in a regular chunk beforehand and then use an inline chunk to display the value in your text. For instance, this document‚Ä¶
```{{r}}
#| label: find-avg-mpg
#| echo: false

avg_mpg <- mean(mtcars$mpg)
```
The average fuel efficiency for cars from 1974 was r round(avg_mpg, 1) miles per gallon.
‚Ä¶ would render to this:

The average fuel efficiency for cars from 1974 was 20.1 miles per gallon.

title: Using Quarto
text:
Output formats
You can specify what kind of document you create when you render in the YAML front matter.
title: "My document"
format:
  html: default
  pdf: default
  docx: default
The indentation of the YAML section matters, especially when you have settings nested under each output type. Here‚Äôs what a typical format section might look like:
---
title: "My document"
author: "My name"
date: "June 4, 2024"
format: 
  html_document: 
    toc: yes
  pdf_document: 
    toc: yes
  word_document: 
    toc: yes
---

Escolha do m√©todo: pesquisa com N-grande (orientada por vari√°veis e busca de efeitos m√©dios) versus pesquisa com N-pequeno (orientada por casos e profundidade).

√âtica em pesquisa: os princ√≠pios de benefic√™ncia, justi√ßa e respeito √†s pessoas; a import√¢ncia do Consentimento Livre e Esclarecido (TCLE).

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text: Here is a list of websites and YouTube channels offering free tutorials and resources for learning R, RStudio, and statistics, now with direct links:

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text: Here is a list of websites and YouTube channels offering free tutorials and resources for learning R, RStudio, and statistics, now with direct links:

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text:
Websites:

R-Project.org: The official website for the R programming language. It contains comprehensive documentation, manuals, and links to various resources. While not structured as a tutorial, it‚Äôs an invaluable reference.
RStudio Education (Posit Education): The official education page from RStudio (now Posit). They offer a wealth of free resources, including webinars, guides, and links to other learning materials.
Quarto tips: Loads of tips to tweak your Quarto website and workbook.

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text:
Books

R for Data Science (r4ds.had.co.nz): A comprehensive free online book by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund, focusing on using R for data science tasks.
Advanced R (adv-r.hadley.nz): Another excellent free online book by Hadley Wickham, delving into more advanced aspects of R programming.

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text:
Free online R courses

R and the Tidyverse for working with data: Basics of R and Tidyverse, including ggplot and data wrnagling;
Introduction to R: Another simple and straightforward online course of R
STAT 545: Data wrangling, exploration, and analysis with R

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text:
Forums

Stack Overflow: A question-and-answer website where you can find solutions to specific R and statistics-related problems.
Cross Validated (stats.stackexchange.com): A dedicated Stack Exchange site for statistics questions.

title: Nice & Free R Courses
text:
YouTube Channels:

Posit PBC: Offical site of the Posit company (Rstudio, Quarto and Tidyverse).
StatQuest with Josh Starmer: While not exclusively focused on R, this channel provides excellent and intuitive explanations of statistical concepts.
Equitable Equations:Offers a wide range of statistics tutorials, many demonstrating implementation in R.
RichardOnData: Provides tutorials and explanations on various data science topics, including R programming and statistical analysis.

Please note that the availability of free content on these platforms may change over time. Always check the specific website or channel for their current offerings.

Generate a boxplot to visualize the distribution of mpg across different cyl (number of cylinders) values.

Fit a linear model to predict mpg using wt (weight) and hp (horsepower). Provide the R code, summarize the model, and interpret the coefficients for wt and hp.

title: Module Overview
text:
Module Aims
This module aims to provide you with advanced skills in interpretation of quantitative and qualitative research data relevant to whole-organism biology, and to develop critical understanding of the ethical considerations involved in the collection of data. The module also aims to underpin the other modules in the Masters Framework by investigating experimental design, ethics, project management and funding.
You will be able to present findings of scientific research in a variety of appropriate ways, as well as critically evaluating, interpreting and relaying knowledge gained from secondary sources to peers.

title: Module Overview
text:
Delivery Mode
The RMDA module takes a blended approach to learning, as such many of the sessions provided, including drop-in sessions, will be via TEAMS. This will allow you to use R in real time, in class, inputting commands and analysing data as we go. The idea behind this is that you will be able to highlight and rectify any issues using R at the point of learning so that you can then continue confidently with tasks in your own time.
Issues will arise especially if this is your first opportunity to use R, that‚Äôs ok, we have a great team to support you so don‚Äôt be afraid to speak up and get the help you need right away. We will discuss how to do this and general guidelines on how you can contribute to the online sessions during our module introduction session (Face to Face classroom session)

title: Module Overview
text:
Attendance and engagement
Please bear in mind that attendance and engagement with module content is vital for successful completion of the module. Please notify your year tutor immediately if you have any concerns regarding an inability to do this over an extended period. The demonstrator team and I will be monitoring engagement and I will contact you and your tutor to ‚Äúcheck in‚Äù if I believe there are issues. If I do check in with you, remember I am doing this out of concern for your learning experience and not to chastise so please engage with these opportunities. title: Module Overview
text:
Knowledge and Understanding
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

Evaluate ethical considerations of scientific research.
Evaluate original research projects using an in-depth understanding of the scientific process.
Demonstrate a level of expertise in highly specialised and advanced research and analytical tools, technical communication and professional skills.

title: Module Overview
text:
Skills, Qualities and Attributes
By the end of this module, you should be able to:

Synthesise and critically analyse scientific data and current literature both generally and specifically and, where appropriate, propose new hypotheses.
Communicate current knowledge and latest research in a specific area of interest to a variety of audiences or specialist levels.
Demonstrate independent or self-directed learning and initiative at a professional or equivalent level.

title: Semana 2: O Modelo Mancha-Corredor-Matriz e a Heterogeneidade
text:
Resumos dos Principais Pontos

1. O Modelo Mancha-Corredor-Matriz (PCM)
Este √© o modelo mais utilizado para representar a estrutura da paisagem, permitindo que ela seja medida, comparada e monitorada ao longo do tempo 1, .

Mancha (Patch): Uma √°rea quase homog√™nea que difere do seu entorno. Seu tamanho, forma e origem (tipo de dist√∫rbio) determinam a estabilidade e a din√¢mica das esp√©cies que nela residem 1, 2.
Corredor (Corridor): Uma faixa linear de vegeta√ß√£o ou habitat que se distingue da matriz e conecta duas ou mais manchas, facilitando fluxos biol√≥gicos 1, 2.
Matriz (Matrix): O elemento espacialmente mais extenso e inter-relacionado. √â o componente que controla a din√¢mica da paisagem, influenciando fluxos de nutrientes, energia e movimento de esp√©cies 2.
Borda (Edge): √â o ec√≥tono entre h√°bitat e n√£o h√°bitat e por sua natureza, √© considerado um h√°itat de ‚Äúmenor qualidade‚Äù em compara√ß√£o √† mancha e ‚Äúmelhor‚Äù que a matriz 2.













2. O Conceito de Heterogeneidade
A paisagem √©, por defini√ß√£o, um mosaico heterog√™neo 1. Essa heterogeneidade n√£o √© est√°tica; ela varia conforme o tempo e o observador 1, .
Principais Fontes de Heterogeneidade:

Ambiente F√≠sico: Varia√ß√µes geol√≥gicas, topogr√°ficas (relevo) e tipos de solo que criam nichos diferenciados 2.







Regime de Dist√∫rbios Naturais: Eventos como fogo, tempestades e pragas que ‚Äúquebram‚Äù a continuidade da vegeta√ß√£o 1, 2.







Perturba√ß√µes Antr√≥picas: A√ß√£o humana atrav√©s do desmatamento, constru√ß√£o de estradas e agricultura, que fragmentam habitats naturais e inserem novos elementos no mosaico.




https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-023-45571-9




3. A Paisagem sob a Lente do Organismo
A distin√ß√£o entre o que √© ‚Äúmancha‚Äù e o que √© ‚Äúmatriz‚Äù depende da esp√©cie estudada. O que para um humano √© uma matriz de pastagem intranspon√≠vel, para um tamandu√° pode ser um habitat preferencial . Portanto, o manejo da paisagem deve considerar a conectividade funcional (capacidade real de movimento) e n√£o apenas a disposi√ß√£o f√≠sica dos elementos 2.
###4 Conectividade Funcional
A conectividade funcional refere-se √† capacidade real de movimento dos organismos atrav√©s dos elementos da paisagem. Diferente da conectividade estrutural, que foca apenas na disposi√ß√£o f√≠sica e espacial das manchas, a funcional considera a intera√ß√£o ecol√≥gica entre a esp√©cie e a p√°isagem
Essa conectividade depende de fatores espec√≠ficos do organismo, como sua capacidade de dispers√£o, escala de percep√ß√£o e o n√≠vel de permeabilidade da matriz para aquele grupo. Manter fluxos funcionais √© vital para garantir o fluxo g√™nico e mitigar os efeitos do isolamento, prevenindo a extin√ß√£o de popula√ß√µes sens√≠veis em paisagens fragmentadas.
 Ilustra√ß√£o dos cinco tipos gerais de m√©tricas e abordagens de conectividade utilizados na literatura em ecossistemas urbanos. (A) A conectividade estrutural conceitualiza manchas discretas em uma matriz uniforme de n√£o-habitat e tipicamente mede dist√¢ncias euclidianas entre manchas de habitat natural ou a quantidade de habitat dentro de uma zona de amortecimento (buffer) ao redor de uma mancha focal. M√©tricas estruturais n√£o tentam capturar varia√ß√µes espec√≠ficas de esp√©cies ou processos. (B) A conectividade de rede em grafos representa as manchas como n√≥s e as liga√ß√µes entre elas (ex: lacunas transpon√≠veis ou corredores) como arestas em uma rede, assumindo que o movimento pode ocorrer apenas entre manchas ligadas por essas arestas. M√©tricas baseadas em grafos podem incorporar informa√ß√µes espec√≠ficas das esp√©cies, como o uso da dist√¢ncia de dispers√£o para determinar quais pares de manchas est√£o vinculados. (C) As m√©tricas de conectividade potencial incorporam explicitamente informa√ß√µes espec√≠ficas das esp√©cies, como dist√¢ncias presumidas de movimento ou dispers√£o, para ponderar as conex√µes poss√≠veis entre manchas para os t√°xons focais. (D) A conectividade funcional conceitualiza paisagens heterog√™neas com custos ou resist√™ncias espec√≠ficos para as esp√©cies de acordo com os tipos de cobertura, baseando-se no quanto uma c√©lula de raster daquele tipo impede o movimento ou aumenta o risco de mortalidade. (E) A conectividade real pode ser estimada a partir do movimento emp√≠rico de indiv√≠duos, do sucesso de dispers√£o ou do fluxo g√™nico registrado entre popula√ß√µes. A valida√ß√£o dos outros quatro tipos de conectividade √© melhor realizada utilizando dados de conectividade real.

  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1980, 2010, 2), 
                     expand = c(0, 0)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 70, 10), 
                     expand = c(0, 0)) +
  guides(fill = "none") +
  labs(y = "Hot dogs and buns", x = NULL) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent", colour = NA),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent", colour = NA),
        axis.ticks.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.25),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_line(linewidth = 0.5, linetype = "dashed"),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

1. Ci√™ncia vs.¬†Senso Comum
A ci√™ncia √© uma metamorfose do senso comum, refinando capacidades que todos possu√≠mos [1]. Enquanto o senso comum √© formado por sentimentos e misticismo, a ci√™ncia exige raz√£o e rigor metodol√≥gico para excluir a subjetividade do pesquisador [2, 3].

Exemplo: O senso comum utiliza um ch√° baseado na tradi√ß√£o familiar para curar dor de est√¥mago. A ci√™ncia investiga os compostos qu√≠micos da planta, realiza testes controlados e isola vari√°veis para validar a efic√°cia [2, 4].

title: Aula 1: Fundamentos e Paradigmas Cient√≠ficos
text:
2. Paradigmas e Revolu√ß√µes (Thomas Kuhn)
O conhecimento cient√≠fico n√£o avan√ßa de forma linear, mas por rupturas disruptivas chamadas mudan√ßas de paradigma [5]. * Ci√™ncia Normal: Fase de estabilidade onde os cientistas trabalham sob as mesmas regras e pressupostos [6]. * Anomalias e Crise: Surgem fatos que o paradigma atual n√£o consegue explicar, gerando instabilidade [6]. * Revolu√ß√£o Cient√≠fica: Ado√ß√£o de um novo paradigma que resolve as anomalias anteriores [6].

Exemplo: A transi√ß√£o da cosmologia ptolomaica (Terra como centro) para a copernicana (Sol como centro) [7].

title: Aula 1: Fundamentos e Paradigmas Cient√≠ficos
text:
3. Bases Epistemol√≥gicas e Ontol√≥gicas
Toda pesquisa est√° ancorada em compromissos filos√≥ficos que determinam o m√©todo [8]. * Ontologia: Trata da natureza da realidade. Questiona: ‚ÄúO que existe?‚Äù [9, 10]. * Epistemologia: Trata de como adquirimos conhecimento. Questiona: ‚ÄúComo posso conhecer o mundo?‚Äù [10, 11].

Exemplo: Um pesquisador decide se a ‚Äúpobreza‚Äù √© uma vari√°vel num√©rica objetiva (renda) ou uma constru√ß√£o social baseada em percep√ß√µes e estigmas [12, 13].

title: Aula 1: Fundamentos e Paradigmas Cient√≠ficos
text:
4. O Cont√≠nuo Naturalismo vs.¬†Construtivismo
Essas posi√ß√µes definem como o pesquisador se relaciona com o objeto de estudo [14, 15]. * Naturalismo (Positivismo): O mundo √© real e independente do observador. Foca em regularidades e leis gerais [14, 16]. * Construtivismo (Interpretativismo): A realidade √© uma constru√ß√£o social. O conhecimento √© subjetivo e depende da intera√ß√£o entre pesquisador e participante [10, 17].

Exemplo: No Naturalismo, o pesquisador observa a ebuli√ß√£o da √°gua sem interferir, apenas mensurando. No Construtivismo, o pesquisador participa de uma comunidade para entender os significados que os membros atribuem aos seus rituais [18, 19].

section: 5. Rigor e Dimens√µes do Desenho de Pesquisa

5. Rigor e Dimens√µes do Desenho de Pesquisa
O desenho de pesquisa √© o plano para usar evid√™ncias para fazer infer√™ncias [20]. Ele deve convencer uma audi√™ncia de c√©ticos de que as decis√µes tomadas s√£o seguras [21]. * Dimens√£o Ampla: Di√°logo te√≥rico e bases metate√≥ricas [22, 23]. * Dimens√£o Pr√°tica: Procedimentos t√©cnicos de coleta e an√°lise [22, 24].
